META.name: title
META.content: Boundary Estimates for the Elastic Wave Equation in Almost Incompressible Materials

page.text: by SIAM. Unauthorized reproduction of this article is prohibited.
2012 Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics
BOUNDARY ESTIMATES FOR THE ELASTIC WAVE EQUATION IN
We study the half-plane problem for the elastic wave equation subject to a free
surface boundary condition, with particular emphasis on almost incompressible materials. A normal
mode analysis is developed to estimate the solution in terms of the boundary data, showing that
. The dependence on the material properties, which is difficult to
analyze by the energy method, is made transparent by our estimates. The normal mode technique is
used to analyze the influence of truncation errors in a finite difference approximation. Our analysis
explains why the number of grid points per wave length must be increased when the shear modulus
) becomes small compared to the first Lam´
materials. When the surface waves are scaled to have unit wave length, our analysis predicts that
method, the grid size can be proportional to (
and illustrate the superior efficiency of a fourth order method.
normal mode analysis, elastic wave propagation, surface waves, grid points per

tic wave equation in a homogeneous isotropic material. By scaling time to give unit
density, the displacement with Cartesian components (
e parameters of the material. We assume that both parameters are constant and
0. The displacement is subject to initial conditions

BOUNDARY ESTIMATES FOR THE ELASTIC WAVE EQUATION
= 0, (1.3) is called a free surface boundary condition.
Since time was scaled to give unit density, the elastic energy is given by
It is well known (see, e.g., Achenbach [1, pp. 59­61]) that the elastic energy satisfies
In particular, without boundary and interior forcing, the elastic energy is conserved,
Note that the elastic energy is a seminorm of the solution. The energy estimate
bounds this seminorm in terms of the initial data and the internal forcing (
For this reason, the elastic wave equation is a well-posed problem. However, the
energy estimate does not provide detailed insight into how the solution depends on
the material parameters, or the boundary data.
It is well known that the elastic wave equation admits compressional and shear
wave solutions. These solutions are body waves. For a material with unit density, the
phase velocity of the compressional and shear waves are
The elastic wave equation also admits Rayleigh surface waves. These waves travel
harmonically along a free surface and decay exponentially away from the surface.
The phase velocity of these waves is ~
9. Hence, the surface waves are always slightly slower
than the shear waves. Recall that the phase velocity of a wave is defined as the ratio
between its wave length and period. In many applications the period of the solution
is determined by the internal forcing functions, i.e.,
as a given. Fixing the period of the solution leads to waves where the wave lengths are
for the compressional and shear waves, respectively.
The wave length of the surface wave is then proportional to ~
the classical theory by Kreiss and Oliger [4], an accurate numerical solution can be
guaranteed if the shortest wave length is not smaller than a constant number of grid
sizes, where the constant depends on the numerical method. This theory indicates
that the grid size should be proportional to
when the period of the solution is
fixed, since the shortest wave length is proportional to
In this paper we are particularly interested in materials with
the grid size predicted by the classical theory is inadequate for accurately calculating
surface waves. As a motivating example, we propagate a Rayleigh surface wave in the
0, subject to a free surface boundary condition at
surface wave propagates harmonically in the
, which gives the surface wave a phase velocity
. To study the resolution requirements for surface waves,
it is convenient to scale the solution such that the surface wave gets unit wave length
. As a result, the period of the surface wave becomes proportional

ized eigenvalues corresponding to surface waves. Here the solution is as smooth as
concepts). We develop a modified equation model of the truncation errors in the
numerical calculation, where we view the discretized boundary conditions as a per-
turbation of the exact boundary conditions. This analysis reveals how perturbations
of the boundary conditions influence the solution, and how the material parameters
To analyze the solution of (1.1)­(1.3), we follow the technique used by Kreiss,
Ortiz, and Petersson [5] and split the problem into two parts. First, we consider a
Cauchy problem, where the definition of the forcing and the initial data are extended
). Secondly, we subtract this solution from the solution of the
half-plane problem to obtain a new half-plane problem, where only the boundary data
do not vanish. This is a very natural procedure because all the difficulties and many
physical phenomena arise at the boundary. The new half-plane problem is analyzed
in detail using the Fourier­Laplace transform method, leading to estimates of the
solution in terms of the boundary data.
The remainder of this paper is organized in the following way. The properties of
the Cauchy problem are briefly discussed in section 2. The normal mode analysis of
the half-plane problem is developed in section 3. We discuss the eigenvalue problem in
sections 3.1­3.2, leading to necessary conditions for a well-posed problem. Boundary
estimates are derived in section 3.3. In section4, weuse the normalmodetheoryto
perform a modified equation analysis of the discretized boundary conditions. This
analysis shows how the number of grid points per surface wave length must be in-
creased to maintain a given error level in the numerical solution when
the surface waves are scaled to have unit wave length, the grid size must be propor-
for the second order method, while it suffices to take
fourth order method. These scalings are confirmed by the numerical experiments in
section 5, illustrating that the fourth order method is significantly more efficient than
the second order approach, in particular for small values of

As we discussed in the introduction, we split the solu-
tion of the half-plane problem (1.1)­(1.3) into a Cauchy problem and a new half-plane
problem, where only the boundary data do not vanish. Hence, the Cauchy problem
satisfies the initial conditions and the interior forcing function. Its solution drives the
solution of the new half-plane problem through a modified boundary forcing function.
For example, when the half-plane problem (1.1)­(1.3) has an interior forcing function
, the solution of the Cauchy problem consists of waves
. The gradient of these waves along
boundary forcing functions for the new half-plane problem.
The estimates obtained in this and the following sections are expressed in Fourier­
Laplace transformed space. It is clear that all these estimates have their counterpart
in physical space. To understand the relation between both types of estimates, we
refer to chapter 7.4 of [3] or chapter 10 of [2].

The Taylor expansion (3.34) gives for small
We now make some observations. Because
value is perturbed along the imaginary axis and remains purely imaginary. Hence the
perturbed problem is well-posed. The value of the perturbed generalized eigenvalue
determines the phase velocity of surface waves in the numerical solution. To avoid
large phase errors, we must therefore keep the perturbation of the generalized eigen-
value small. If we accept a relative error in the phase speed of size ,where 0
we have to choose the grid size

For a fourth order accurate method, where the leading order truncation error
The number of grid points per surface wave length to maintain an -error in the phase
0, the number of grid points per surface wave length grows much
slower for the fourth than the second order accurate method.
For other truncation error perturbations of the boundary conditions, such as a
) becomes complex. If the truncation error coefficient has the
wrong sign, the perturbed problem gets eigenvalues with positive real part. From
Lemma 3.1 we know that such problems are ill-posed. Furthermore, the factor
in the denominator of (4.3) shows that the rate of the exponential growth can get
0. It is therefore very difficult to compensate for such
growth with an artificial dissipation term.
For a second order hyperbolic equation, energy
conservation ensures that all eigenvalues of the spatial operator are either real and
negative, or zero. The same property applies to the discretized problem. To avoid
any spurious growth in the numerical solutions, it is therefore important to use a dis-
cretization that also satisfies energy conservation. Such a discretization was derived
for the three-dimensional elastic wave equation in Nilsson et al [7]. In the present
work, we use the corresponding discretization for the two-dimensional case. This nu-
merical method discretizes the elastic wave equation with a second order accurate,
energy conserving finite difference method on a Cartesian grid with constant grid
sizes in space and time. The second order method was recently generalized to fourth
ogreen and Petersson [8], and we use both the second and fourth
order methods in the following numerical experiments. Note that our finite difference
methods are based on solving the elastic wave equation as a second order hyper-
bolic system using summation by parts operators. These methods are fundamentally
different from the commonly used staggered grid method developed by Vireaux [9],
Levander [6], and others, which is based on solving the elastic wave equation as a first
Downloaded 07/14/15 to 168.150.3.95. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php
by SIAM. Unauthorized reproduction of this article is prohibited.

To accurately solve this problem numerically, it is necessary to resolve the short
shear waves on the computational grid. For this problem, we define the resolution in
terms of the number of grid points per shear wave length,

We have developed a normal mode analysis for the half-plane
problem of the elastic wave equation subject to a free surface boundary condition.
Our analysis allows the solution to be estimated in terms of the boundary data,
showing that the solution is as smooth as the boundary forcing. Hence, using the
properties is transparent in our estimates. Using a modified equation approach, the
normal mode technique was extended to analyze the influence of truncation errors in a
finite difference approximation. Our analysis explains why the number of grid points
per surface wave length must be very large to accurately calculate surface waves in
1. To obtain a fixed error in the phase velocity of Rayleigh
surface waves, our analysis predicts that the number of grid points per surface wave
for a second order method, when
fourth order method, the analysis shows that it suffices to use
scalings have been confirmed by numerical experiments.
It is theoretically possible to derive stable finite difference schemes that give higher
than fourth order accuracy. These methods use wider stencils that are more expensive
to evaluate, but for the surface wave problem it would suffice to use
points per surface wave length, where
is the order of accuracy. For sufficiently small
, these methods should be more efficient as the order of accuracy increases.
However, numerical experiments must be performed to evaluate how small
must be to compensate for the higher computational complexity of these very high
The normal mode analysis presented here is restricted to homogeneous materials.
It can, in principle, be generalized to layered materials with piecewise constant prop-
erties subject to jump conditions across the interfaces. The normal mode analysis
would be straightforward to extend to the three-dimensional elastic wave equations
case, there are compressional, shear, and surface wave solutions. In particular, the
two-dimensional Rayleigh waves discussed here correspond to planar surface wave
dimensional surface waves require a similar number of grid points per wave length as
in the two-dimensional case. Since the same resolution is required in all three spatial
directions, it becomes even more beneficial to use a fourth or higher order accurate
numerical method in the three-dimensional case.
